image.altText: Trump in front of a US flag, raising his fist

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump is indicted on criminal charges. Follow live.

title.children: Trump indicted by grand jury on four charges over 2020 election, special counsel gives statement

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Special counsel Jack Smith has delivered a short statement about today's indictment. He says since the attack on the US Capitol, the Department of Justice has "remained committed to ensuring accountability for those criminally responsible for what happened that day". Smith: This case is brought consistent with that commitment, and our investigation of other individuals continues. In this case, my office will seek a speedy trial so that our evidence can be 
tested in court and judged by a jury of citizens. In the meantime, I must emphasise that the indictment is only an allegation and that the defendant must be presumed innocent until proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt in a court of law.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prosecutors say they will seek a 'speedy' trial for Donald Trump

children.content: Special counsel
Jack Smith
has delivered a short statement about today's indictment.
He says since the attack on the US Capitol, the Department of Justice has "remained committed to ensuring accountability for those criminally responsible for what happened that day".

props.alt: A man with a beard wearing a suit and tie speaks from washington.

children.content: Smith:

This case is brought consistent with that commitment, and our investigation of other individuals continues. In this case, my office will seek a speedy trial so that our evidence can be 
tested in court and judged by a jury of citizens.
In the meantime, I must emphasise that the indictment is only an allegation and that the defendant must be presumed innocent until proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt in a court of law.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: According to the indictment, Mr Trump is alleged to have "enlisted co-conspirators to assist him in his criminal efforts to overturn the legitimate results of the 2020 presidential election and retain power". Here's how they're described in the indictment: An attorney who was willing to spread knowingly false claims and pursue strategies that the Defendant's 2020 re-election campaign attorneys would not An attorney who devised and attempted to implement a strategy to leverage the Vice President's ceremonial role overseeing the certification proceeding to obstruct the certification of the presidential election. An attorney whose unfounded claims of election fraud the Defendant privately acknowledged to others sounded "crazy". Nonetheless, the Defendant embraced and publicly amplified co-conspirator three's disinformation. A Justice Department official who worked on civil matters and who, with the Defendant, attempted to use the Justice Department to open sham election crime investigations and influence state legislatures with knowingly false claims of election fraud An attorney who assisted in devising and attempting to implement a plan to submit fraudulent slates of presidential electors to obstruct the certification proceeding A political consultant who helped implement a plan to submit fraudulent slates of presidential electors to obstruct the certification proceeding
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Donald Trump is alleged to have had six co-conspirators — here's what we know about them

children.content: According to the indictment, Mr Trump is alleged to have "enlisted co-conspirators to assist him in his criminal efforts to overturn the legitimate results of the 2020 presidential election and retain power".
Here's how they're described in the indictment:
An attorney who was willing to spread knowingly false claims and pursue strategies that the Defendant's 2020 re-election campaign attorneys would not

An attorney who devised and attempted to implement a strategy to leverage the Vice President's ceremonial role overseeing the certification proceeding to obstruct the certification of the presidential election.

An attorney whose unfounded claims of election fraud the Defendant privately acknowledged to others sounded "crazy". Nonetheless, the Defendant embraced and publicly amplified co-conspirator three's disinformation.

A Justice Department official who worked on civil matters and who, with the Defendant, attempted to use the Justice Department to open sham election crime investigations and influence state legislatures with knowingly false claims of election fraud
An attorney who assisted in devising and attempting to implement a plan to submit fraudulent slates of presidential electors to obstruct the certification proceeding
A political consultant who helped implement a plan to submit fraudulent slates of presidential electors to obstruct the certification proceeding

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to the indictment, which says Mr Trump widely repeated false election claims to "erode public faith in the administration of the election". It alleges that Mr Trump also "pursued unlawful means of discounting legitimate votes and subverting the election results", perpretrating "three criminal conspiracies" in the process. "Each of these conspiracies — which built on the widespread mistrust the Defendant was creating through pervasive and destabilizing lies about election fraud — targeted a bedrock funciton of the United States federal government: the nation's process of collecting, counting, and certifying the results of the presidential election," the indictment reads.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Donald Trump created an 'intense national atmosphere of mistrust and anger'

children.content: That's according to the indictment, which says Mr Trump widely repeated false election claims to "erode public faith in the administration of the election".
It alleges that Mr Trump also "pursued unlawful means of discounting legitimate votes and subverting the election results", perpretrating "three criminal conspiracies" in the process.

"Each of these conspiracies — which built on the widespread mistrust the Defendant was creating through pervasive and destabilizing lies about election fraud — targeted a bedrock funciton of the United States federal government: the nation's process of collecting, counting, and certifying the results of the presidential election," the indictment reads.

image.altText: Donald Trump pictured making a fist while speaking into microphone at podium with US flag in background.

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump has been indicted on four charges related to attempts to overturn the 2020 US presidential election.

title.children: Trump faces charges including conspiracy to defraud US, obstruction of official proceeding

image.altText: Close up of Nicole Asher

image.altText: Unidentified child drawing.

image.altText: A mobile phone is held in a person's hand at the ASX in Sydney

items.synopsis: The Australian dollar has slumped more than 1 per cent overnight and Wall Street has ended mainly lower. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Australian dollar slumps on RBA pause, US stocks end mixed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Global credit ratings agency Fitch Ratings has cut the US credit rating from AAA to AA+. Fitch says the downgrade reflects the expected fiscal deterioration over the next three years, a high and growing general government debt burden, and the erosion of governance. In May, Fitch threatened to cut the AAA credit rating because of the US debt ceiling standoff. "In Fitch's view, there has been steady deterioration in standards of governance over the last 20 years, including on fiscal and debt matters, notwithstanding the June bipartisan agreement to suspend the debt limit until January 2025." "The repeated debt limit political standoffs and last minute resolutions have eroded confidence in fiscal management." Fitch is also predicting a mild recession for the US economy later this year and early next year because of high interest rates, weakening business investment and a slowdown in spending. It expects the Federal Reserve to lift interest rates one more time to 5.5 per cent to 5.75 per cent by next month. Standard and Poor's downgraded the US credit rating from the top AAA rating in 2011 after the US managed to avoid a debt default. Moody's Investors Service has maintained the US credit rating at AAA. Credit ratings are used by investors to assess a country or company's ability to repay their debts. The reality is a AA+ credit rating is still very high and won't have much impact on the borrowing costs of the US. But not every one agrees with Fitch's decision including former Treasury secretary Larry Summers.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US loses AAA credit rating

children.content: Global credit ratings agency Fitch Ratings has cut the US credit rating from AAA to AA+.
Fitch says the downgrade reflects the expected fiscal deterioration over the next three years, a high and growing general government debt burden, and the erosion of governance.
In May, Fitch threatened to cut the AAA credit rating because of the US debt ceiling standoff.

"In Fitch's view, there has been steady deterioration in standards of governance over the last 20 years, including on fiscal and debt matters, notwithstanding the June bipartisan agreement to suspend the debt limit until January 2025."
"The repeated debt limit political standoffs and last minute resolutions have eroded confidence in fiscal management."
Fitch is also predicting a mild recession for the US economy later this year and early next year because of high interest rates, weakening business investment and a slowdown in spending.
It expects the Federal Reserve to lift interest rates one more time to 5.5 per cent to 5.75 per cent by next month.
Standard and Poor's downgraded the US credit rating from the top AAA rating in 2011 after the US managed to avoid a debt default.
Moody's Investors Service has maintained the US credit rating at AAA.
Credit ratings are used by investors to assess a country or company's ability to repay their debts.
The reality is a AA+ credit rating is still very high and won't have much impact on the borrowing costs of the US.
But not every one agrees with Fitch's decision including former Treasury secretary Larry Summers.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rio Tinto's boss says he's confident that China will roll out major stimulus to boost its flagging economy. China's economy is slowing down and Beijing has announced small measures to boost growth, although there's been no sign yet of the big cash splashes of the past. But Rio chief executive Jakob Stausholm has told Kirsten Aiken on The Business that he is "cautiously optimistic" about China. "I'm very encouraged by hearing that the government in China acknowledge that there are opportunities to strengthen the economy. "And experience tells us that when they acknowledge that there is an issue, that they know exactly how to address the issue." China released additional policy guidelines this week but no concrete measures to boost its economy and household spending, leaving investors disappointed. Here's Kirsten Aiken's interview with Jakob Stausholm.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rio Tinto boss confident of China stimulus

featuredLink.title: Can China stave off a crisis? Rio boss hopes it can

children.content: Rio Tinto's boss says he's confident that China will roll out major stimulus to boost its flagging economy.
China's economy is slowing down and Beijing has announced small measures to boost growth, although there's been no sign yet of the big cash splashes of the past.
But Rio chief executive Jakob Stausholm has told Kirsten Aiken on The Business that he is "cautiously optimistic" about China.
"I'm very encouraged by hearing that the government in China acknowledge that there are opportunities to strengthen the economy.
"And experience tells us that when they acknowledge that there is an issue, that they know exactly how to address the issue."
China released additional policy guidelines this week but no concrete measures to boost its economy and household spending, leaving investors disappointed.
Here's Kirsten Aiken's interview with Jakob Stausholm.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog. I'm Sue Lannin. The Australian dollar slumped by 1.6 per cent overnight after the Reserve Bank left official interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent. US stocks were mixed with the Dow Jones index modestly rising, but the S & P 500 and Nasdaq lost ground. That's ahead of major company profit results this week and the latest US employment data. New data showed the US manufacturing industry contracted in July but at a slower pace than in June, which was the lowest reading since May 2020. It was the ninth month of contraction for the Institute of Supply Management's manufacturing index. There was a gradual improvement in new orders, but factory employment dropped to a three-year low. Other surveys showed manufacturing contracting globally including in Germany, France, the United Kingdom and China. Grab a coffee and let's go.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian dollar tumbles and US stocks end mixed

children.content: Good morning and welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog. I'm Sue Lannin.
The Australian dollar slumped by 1.6 per cent overnight after the Reserve Bank left official interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent.
US stocks were mixed with the Dow Jones index modestly rising, but the S
P 500 and Nasdaq lost ground.
That's ahead of major company profit results this week and the latest US employment data.
New data showed the US manufacturing industry contracted in July but at a slower pace than in June, which was the lowest reading since May 2020.
It was the ninth month of contraction for the Institute of Supply Management's manufacturing index.
There was a gradual improvement in new orders, but factory employment dropped to a three-year low.
Other surveys showed manufacturing contracting globally including in Germany, France, the United Kingdom and China.
Grab a coffee and let's go.
